title: Giant baby boy weighing 14.7 pounds is born in China
title_page: Giant baby boy weighing 14.7 pounds is born in China | Daily Mail Online
text:
A Chinese woman has given birth to a son weighing a whopping 14.8 pounds (6.7kg).
The baby, one of the heaviest newborns the country has seen, weighed twice as much as an average Chinese newborn boy.
The father, surnamed Wang, was thrilled that his son is so strong and he gave him a nickname Kang Kang, meaning 'healthy' in Chinese, according to local media.
He's a big boy: A 35-year-old Chinese woman has given birth to a son weighing a staggering 14.7 pounds. His father was thrilled and name him Kang Kang, meaning 'healthy'
Kang Kang was born through a Caesarean Section on March 6 in the Daxing Hospital in Xi'an, China's Shaanxi Province, according to People's Daily Online, citing a report from Huashang Daily.
He was born in good health and measured 22.8 inches (58cm) long, nearly twice the length of an average baby.
Mr Wang said that his wife, 35, was a little 'chubby' and that she had suffered from gestational diabetes.
As a result of the diabetes, the woman suffered from eating disorders, according to a video report by Xinhua News Agency.
However, his father told a reporter from Huashang Daily that his wife's diet had comprised mainly coarse food grain during her pregnancy.
He said that his son must have been 'too good at absorbing nutrients in his mother's belly', hence being so heavy.
CHINA'S BIG ISSUE: OBESITY IS ON THE RISE Prevalence of childhood overweight rose from 1.11 per cent to 9.62 per cent between 1985 and 2010.
Overweight and obesity were found to be most common among boys living in urban regions (23.2 per cent).
World Obesity Federation expects China to have the most obese children in the world in 2025.
The number of obese children aged between five and 18 will reach 48 million in a decade. Source: WHO, CCTV News
Apparently before Kang Kang was born, Mr Wang and Mrs Wang had been told that their baby could be large, but they were surprised to learn that he weighed in at 14.8 pounds (6.7kg).
After Mr Wang shared pictures of his baby on his social media account, his relatives were said to be envious of his 'big son'.
The couple already have an eight-year-old daughter.
She was also heavy at birth, weighing 11 pounds (5kg). The father said his daughter exercises regularly and her weight is normal now.
She advised Mr and Mrs Wang to manage Kang Kang's diet and to keep a close look at his weight - so that the child wouldn't suffer from illnesses, such as high blood pressure and high blood cholesterol.
The doctor also said many Chinese families prefer to have bigger babies, so they would overfeed expectant mothers.
However, Dr Liu warned against the tradition as excessive nutrients could lead to illnesses in the baby; it could also increase the difficulties of the mother's labour.
In China, a baby is categorised as 'overweight' if he or she weighs more than 8.8 pounds (4kg) within an hour of birth.
A newborn Chinese boy weighs 3.32kg on average while a newborn Chinese girl weighs 3.21kg, according to the country's Ministry of Health.
